WRITING.TEXT:
No questions are stupid! Could you give an example though?
When you talk about the interval between C and F# you say it's an augmented fourth but when talking about C and Gb (which are the same keys on a piano) you say it's a diminished fifth (at least in Swedish idk if I translated it correctly)
So what do you mean with enharmonic?
Edit: [This Wikipedia article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enharmonic) may be helpful!

On stringed instruments like the violin the note(s) e.g. C# and Db is(are) not the same. But they are on a modern piano. Before equal temperament, one key would be as perfect as if you played it on a violin, but all other keys would be off. Today all keys (on a piano) are off, but only sliiiightly. Google it! :)

Thank you! After watching some of his lectures on YouTube, i was thinking this total serialism was something he "came up with", but now I have it confirmed as well as a lot more information! This is so interesting! This was very helpful! Thank you very much! :)
Edit: added "" and just wanted to clarify, knowing that he was part of the group that developed this total serialism is good enough, knowing all other things he did during his life, makes him very noteworthy in music history, and I'm trying just to figure out what role in music history he had, so this helped me a lot! :D
Yeah, I know quite a lot about the stuff he did, except exactly what that he brought to serialism specifically. This has helped me a little, thanks.

WRITING.TITLE: [Question] What did Stockhausen actually do for serialism?
WRITING.TEXT:
I've read some about it, but I can't yet really grasp exactly why he was so important. Does anyone have a great source I can read more from, or maybe simply describe what differences he largely made? Thank you! :)

Edit 2: I've gotten some good answers over at r/musictheory so don't feel bad if you see this post and don't feel that my question has been answered! :)

First, personally, I think "River Flows In You" is disgustingly cheesy and is not harmonically interesting at all. But with that said, it's not too hard to play, I think you could give it a shot. I much prefer "Spring Rain" by Yiruma if you want music in a similar style, but I would say that's just a tad harder to play.

WRITING.TITLE: Cubase LE Giveaway!
WRITING.TEXT:
I got a serial code for Cubase LE with my new sound card. I don't need it (Logic 4 life) so I figured I could give it away.
It's my birthday today, and I'm giving away things, huh :)
So comment an explanation on why you could use this software and what you intend to do with it. I think it's mostly useful for newbies that want to get in to creating their own music, or for outlaws that have pirated their DAW and wants to come clean.
I will check in again in 24h and choose a winner (if anyone even has participated :P )
Good luck!
[The software I'm talking about](https://www.steinberg.net/en/landing_pages/cubase_le_8/download.html)
Edit: A word
Edit 2: This giveaway has ended! Thank you for your interest!

I do mostly orchestral work, but also ambience and experimental electronic, chiptune etc I also do some SFX

Yes you can charge it while using it! (That's what happens when it's in the dock, but trough the wall or with power banks are okay as well.)
Depending on how comfortable you find the joycon, you wanna get the pro controller. Most seem to find the joycon the most comfortable when having them separated, without the extra strap. I personally prefer using the included grip.
You probably want to get a sd card sooner or later
ZELDA IS MUST HAVE.

I too can confirm that I personally have none of these issues! However, my right joycon analoug-stick wasn't totally smooth, but I just went back to the store and got it replaced! :)
The charging thing seems to me just be that it charges slower while docked and playing a heavy game lik zelda. I however got it to a 100% while playing zelda, (don't remember for how long though).
I know that there is a chance that the left joycon dissconnects. Maybe nintendo already has done something about this with the one day update. I haven't experienced this while close to my tv/console, but when I walked away with the controllers, the left one disconnected while the right one still could sustain a connection (ca 10 meters trough 3 walls).
Haven't heard anything about crashing.

I guess the dock can scratch the screen if you try to scratch the screen with the dock. But unlikely otherwise.

School

Before everyone got their own macbooks we had a small room with lot's of computers with windows xp. They used to be locked down so you couldn't download stuff or access stuff you weren't supposed to. However, if you where a little tricky, you could change the background image (they where just blue). So I wrote "this computer is hacked" on the wallpaper and made it green instead of blue. Cool shit I know. Teachers that doesn't now anything about computers didn't think it was very funny though.
